Ein Fall für schlaue Füchse

Spy Fox in "Dry Cereal" ist ein Point and Click Adventure, das für ein jüngeres Publikum gemacht ist, jedoch auch für Erwachsene ganz lustig sein kann. Es geht hier um einen Fuchs, der eine Homage an James Bond ist und somit auch das ein oder andere technische Spielzeug mit sich bringt. Da die Story von Anfang an eigentlich schon ziemlich durchgeknallt ist, sage ich nur, dass diese gelungen ist und man sie selbst erleben muss.

Grafisch hat das Spiel seine ganz eigene Note, die stimmig zusammenpasst. Auch Soundtechnisch hat das Spiel gute deutsche Sprecher zu bieten und Soundeffekte, die manchmal albern sind, aber das soll ja auch so.

Alles im Allem ist das Spiel also gut, aber definitiv nicht den Vollpreis wert. Ich habe alle Spiele im Bundle gekauft, als dieses im Angebot war. Wer also Spy Fox interessant findet, kann dem eine Chance geben, aber der Daumen nach oben kommt nur sehr zögerlich von meiner Seite.

31556984.review: Spy Fox is an excellent series of point-and-click style adventure games for a younger audience. However, it still can draw fans from well outside of its recommended play range, especially if you played this game when you were young. The puzzles are both challenging and simple at times, and you possibly are aided by small memories of playing this game when you were little bubbling to the surface. I recommend this game wholeheartedly to anyone who played it when they were young, regardless of whether or not they beat it; anyone who has enjoyed other Humongous Entertainment games; or anyone looking for a fun romp of a game that they may have missed when it was first released. It has multiple routes and endings as well that solidify its replayability value. Please don't miss out on this suave fox of expert espionage!

27310871.review:
This G-rated game is best played with an adult. 

No, no, there's nothing spooky, gory, or crude about this game. It's a wonderful parody/homage to Get Smart and James Bond, with characters and a story that's both cute and action-packed. I played plenty of this game back when I was a [strike]kid[/strike] cub, and there's also a great 'Go Fish' minigame you can find that you can spend a lot of time on.

It's a more simpler issue of vocabulary. The recommended age for Spy Fox is a couple years higher than Putt-Putt or Freddi Fish, and it's because Spy Fox's theme is all about going to exotic locales and encountering foreign people and concepts. I still remember a moment or two where I was stuck in the game and just played Go Fish, because I couldn't understand what was being asked for. It's not a serious problem, but you do need to pay attention to what's being said.

...or maybe I was just terrible at English.

24150258.review:
SpyFox is bit of a cult classic to those that played H.E. games as a child back in the mid-late 90's to early 2000's for Wins 95, 98, and X (Vista and later requires a Emulator, which the steam releases provides).

Able to play this again was a huge nostalgia trip for me, and discovered a few gags I never saw before, somehow, or references I didn't understand as a child. It has aged well, and is great for kids or anyone new to adventure games.

In this game, SpyFox has to stop a goat named William the Kid from ruining the dairy market by replacing cow milk with goat milk. You're sent to a fictional greek island to met the rest of your team: Monkey Penny, Prof. Quack, and maybe a bug named Walter Wireless.

There are alternate paths that are designed everytime you start up the game: How to get from point A to B, what characters you'll see, how you'll interact with them, and what you need to do to beat the game, along with a hidden way to get the true ending (with a fixed solution). There is some puzzle solving with two mini-games: Run-and-gun side scrolling "Happy Sub Time" and the famous Go-Fish with Mr. Big Pig, whom never lost, yet.

This game and other majority H.E. adventure games are short, since the target audience was for children, afterall.

Get the Spy Fox complete set or the H.E. complete set if you liked the other franchises from H.E., or to share your child hood experience with your children with games that are actually meant for their age group, and not give them CoD and/or an Xbox like any bad parent would do.

23480773.review:
Spy Fox in Dry Cereal is the first in the Spy Fox adventure games made by Humongous Entertainment back in the 90s. The game takes place in a Zootopia-esque world where all of the characters are anthropomorphic animals. In it you play as a Maxwell Smart/James Bond parody character named "Spy Fox" who is assigned to crack a suspicious shortage of the world's milk inorder to prevent a worldwide epidemic of "dry cereal".

Much like all of Humongous's other games Spy Fox is a very kid friendly adventure game. It takes place in a cutesy inoffensive world and the plot is very childlike and easy to understand. What is different about it compared to other Humongous games is you now have the ability to select alternate dialogue options from floating dialogue balloons. This doesn't impact much however but it does make the game feel more like a Saturday morning cartoon show as a result. 

It also has random elements like Freddi Fish and Pajama Sam. Only in Spy Fox it's slightly more involved in that the story branches off a little, and how the story progresses varies from playthrough to playthrough. It's still fairly short and really easy for a point and click adventure game but it does deliver a slight amount of replayability as a result.

It's a nice game and nice series but it appeals to children best. Since it does a good job at being a simple easy to follow kids game. Alternatively if you're a fan of constant amounts of animal puns it'll appeal to you too.

22811120.review:
This is a bit of a tough recommend, since I grew up with Spy Fox as a child. Much like Pajama Sam, I had to take off my rose-tinted nostalgia glasses to really look at this game and...

...Yeah, I don't like it as much as I used to.

Just because I have a thumbs down on your favorite childhood game doesn't mean you should instantly dislike my review. I'm going to go into detailed reasons why I don't like Spy Fox as much now. I'm not saying I hate this game, I just don't see it as this incredibly entertaining game anymore, since I'm- you know- an adult.

Spy Fox follows the James Bond parody of... Spy Fox, as he investigates a mysterious Greek island to uncover a secret villain's plot involving stealing... all the milk... then flooding the earth... so the cows get blamed... and then they'll get arrested, which means no more cow milk... then he'll get rich selling goat milk.

What the hell?

I understand most people will say, "It's made for kids!" to which I reply, "Why are you making excuses for bad story-telling?". I like a good deal of movies and video games out there, and  I enjoy just as many products made for children. I like Avatar: The Last Airbender, Spirited Away, and Pajama Sam #1 because they were made for kids, but also had adults in mind while they were making their stories. I never expect the most perfect story ever, but at least some sense of logic would be appreciated.

On top of that, Spy Fox's voice was very... annoying to me. It didn't bother me as much when I was seven, but now, every time he breaks the game by saying a really dumb pun just immediately makes me sigh and roll my eyes. He's supposed to be charming and witty, but he comes across as the nerd in school who thinks its funny to have your jokes revolve around the same topic or remain the same type of joke.

The actual gameplay is pretty meh. It's a Humongous game, so you know what's in store. Lots of clicking. But the story remains the same, with only two distinct variations between achieving your final goal, and three random keys to the M.W.D. (Milky Weapon of Destruction) that you'll have to solve one per game.

That, and there's oftentimes some annoying backtracking. Especially if you want to defeat the Kawk-a-Doodle Foo guy, you have to go ALL the way back to the cafe (Yes, I mispelled C-O-C-K-a-Doodle Foo on purpose. I hate being forcibly censored). If you forget one spy gadget, you have to return to the MobCo base, and grab that gadget in order to advance.

To me this game, seems significantly less developed than Pajama Sam. I mean, Pajama Sam wasn't perfect, but there was a sense of exploring an entirely new world. It was beautiful to look at and to discover the three missing items in it. In Spy Fox, the island is colored with different greys, tans, and puke greens. It's just not very appealing to look at. And you stay in the city/ocean/secret base almost the whole game. The only time you get to see more of the island is when you're driving, and even then it's not much.

Pajama Sam also had structure to it, but it was flexible enough for there to be nine different variations of games. Spy Fox has about six. Again, not a big deal, but it feels severely more limited when the only difference between playthroughs is whether you go out to sea or drive, and which key you'll be grabbing this time. It doesn't feel like I'm a spy. It feels like I'm going through the motions. And that might be because I've beaten this game a ton as a kid.

Besides that, there are plenty of good things in this game. There's tons of little references to James Bond and even a ton of things that have nothing to do with spies. Fox says, "Penny, I've got your number!" at one point, which I thought was cute. The actual animals living in this world stick out a lot and are both very well-drawn and colored. You can tell that two different people worked on the backgrounds and characters- or perhaps it was the same guy with two different ideas in mind.

That, and I like the gadget and question system. Being able to hold onto 4 gadget at a time for whatever might pop up is really practical, as is gathering questions about characters and asking people about them.

Plus, the game does a good job at making you feel like a spy. From playing "Go Fish!", to arming a missile system to blow up a door, to laser-cutting through a door- the game makes sure you feel like a secret agent on a mission.

But, you know, for kids. Whatever.

While its charm has worn on me, it certainly hasn't for the rabid Humongous fans out there. I still enjoyed playing through it, but I just feel like it's not as good as how I remember it. I do remember having much fonder memories of Spy Fox 3, and we'll see if that still carries. But my final score for Spy Fox in Dry Cereal is a 5/10. To me, the pros in this game pretty much equal the cons.

21063208.review:
Ein Stückchen Kindheit wieder ausgekramt. Himmel, hab ich dieses Spiel geliebt!
Spyfox ist ein schönes "Point&Klick Adventure" Spiel für die jüngeren unter uns. 
Die Rätsel sind einfach gestrickt, die Animationen bzw. Zeichnungen und Sprüche kinderfreundlich.

Im Spiel selbst gibt es noch zwei "Minispiele". Einmal das Spiel an der Spionuhr ("Fröhliches Ubot") und das Quartett Spiel.

Das schöne an Spy Fox ist, dass jede neue Spielrunde anders ist.
Andere Gegenstände übernehmen die "Hauptrolle", andere Kombinationen müssen erfolgen, andere Storyinhalte erscheinen. Jede neue Runde verlangt demnach eine andere Kombination von Gegenständen und Charakteren.

Ich habs mir aus Nostalgie Gründen gekauft. Wenn man Langeweile hat und keine Lust auf ein "anspruchsvolles" Spiel hat, ist Spy Fox eine nette "Abwechslung" bzw. Reise in die Kindheit.

20984239.review:
Spy fox in Dry Cereal is the first in the triology from my younger childhood. A great sense of nostalgia and a whole lot of fun.

Pros:
1.Puzzles were always interesting. Whether you were knockin aligators unconcious with the power of food or solving lazer-mirror puzzles they were always fun. As a teen now with a little bit of rememberance puzzles were easier but still fun.
2.Interesting gameplay mechanics. One aspect of the game was interrogating characters about other characters for information. Timed minigames were also thrown in causing some trouble to even the older of players. Gadgets are interesting and fun.
3.There are 2 endings. I've only completed one as of now. So I'll be back after completing the rest of the series again.
4.Humor. There are lots of puns, jokes, and James Bond references of which I was quite fond of. Also WANNA SEE MY TATTOO

Cons:
1: Go Fish. Really the only con. Go Fish was one of the minigames. Basically I bought a Jar of Trinkets and used them to gamble with this fat pig. We had to play Go Fish. I swear that pig had a dwarf hiding in the one sided mirror disco ball feeding him info on my card stack with a earpiece. Either that or he was psychic. Too many frustrating tries came out of this. Also guess what your reward is. Nothing. You get jack shit! It was supposed to be a fun minigame but it was not fun. So if you play this game. Stay away from the fucking pig. There's no point to deal with annoyance. Edit: Nevermind what I said. You have to beat him in one of the paths. 

Story:
This time Spy Fox is up against William The Kid. He's a goat who wants to steal all the cow milk right from their udders. 
How does he plan to carry this heinous deed out?
Well first he kidnaps Mr. Udderly, a cow that milks cows for milk... What the fuck mate. That's like me farming woman's tits for milk so I can sell it to lil kids. Oh shit I think that is a real thing.
Anyway he then plans to flood the world with all the milk so that he can send out tsunamis of the milk onto the world to kill everyone.
Then he'll point his finger at the cows blaming them for it so they end up in jail. These cows will have to deal with Prison Rape for the rest of their lives. Taking it in the backside in Alcatraz for an eternity.
Then he'll make everyone drink goat's milk. Which honestly the last part doesn't sound half bad. I quite like Goat Cheese. 
Anyway like usual you and your fursona: Spy Fox have to stop him.
To do so we must turn of his Milky Weapon Of Destruction (Sounds like a killer name for a dick. Kappa.), free the cows, and throw this goat bitch into Alcatraz!
It's fun. 
Play it especially if you played it as a child and are looking for a nostalgasm. If you're a furry then maybe this is the game for you.

17086523.review: Spy Fox was my absolute favorite game as a child, I must have replayed 20+ times. As an adult, it's still a blast.

17056766.review: Spy Fox was another game from Humongous Entertainment I never got to play as a kid, up until now. This franchise is a take on the James Bond films except with anthropomorphic animals as characters. You play as a suave Fox name Spy Fox who is a mix between Mr. Fox from Fantastic Mr. Fox and Maxwell Smart from Get Smart. Your mission is to prevent a mastermind named William the Kid from abducting all of the diary cows in the world and replacing the milk supply with goat's milk. With an arsenal of gadgets and a band of allies, Fox is likely to prevail in his mission. Spoofing on spy thrillers have been done countless times for games, shows, and movies. However this game is really enjoyable with the humor and each character having a unique personality prevents this game from being dull. If you love the Pajama Sam games, this one is a must have. Plus you get the option to play the game twice to see two alternate endings depending how well you do on your quest.

16997949.review: Everytime I come back and play it, I find a new line which cracks me up. Thank you HE!

16928697.review: This doesn't even feel like a kid's game really. There's a ton of spy references (naturally) and the plot has a much grander scale than any of the other humongous series, as well as the oldest protagonist. I mean, yeah, it's definitely still a kid's game in terms of puzzle design and the style and all, but I will admit that despite having no nostalgia for this series whatever, having not played it before, I enjoyed this game in its own right a fair bit. There's nothing like in the other games that kind of makes you cringe with how kiddy it is, the game's got decent replayability (the first half of the game has two almost mutually-exclusive quests and there are three different quests in the second half, plus an extra ending scene that you can actually miss - it's a really weird but interesting game structure for a humongous game). Would definitely recommend this one, it's pretty enjoyable.

16901914.review:
I never played this one as a child, but as an adult who has recently entered into my first job, I figured I'd treat myself and instead of playing the demo 100 times like I did back then, I'd just buy the game. I really do like this one, especially since it has a more Bond-y feel than the other two (what with Russian Blue and all). 

It's not my favorite (Operation Ozone reigns supreme in my heart), but it's definitely a good one. It was nice to revisit Spy Fox.

16879049.review:
Humongus Entertainment rocked a lot of people's childhoods.  With games like 'Spy Fox in 'Dry Cereal'' it's not too hard to see why.  I confess this game sure rocked my childhood too, something about it was just perfect for my prepubescent mind.  Recently I was gifted this game and I had the opportunity to play it again, a bit out of the target demographic, but oh well, who really pays much attention to that anyway.  I thought maybe it might've become dated and dull as the decades passed by, but wow was I mistaken.  The game holds up really well today, surprisingly well, even.  It is dripping with it's own unique, unmistakable style (Humongous Entertainment seems to be good at that).  And well, in short, it is just a really entertaining game, I think modern game makers seem to forget that with the push for realistic graphics.  

Story wise, Spy Fox is silly and simple, but all the basic elements are there and it never falters in its zany pace.  You can tell from the title alone that it is probably a spoof of Bond-like espionage films/games, and that's exactly what it is!  You play as Spy Fox, who probably could have been renammed sly fox because of his sheer, suave cunning, he has a bit of an ego, but it all just adds to the charm.  He works at a spy agency with Monkeypenny (a monkey) and Professor Quack (no prises for guessing what species he is).  The plot is kickstarted when, on a food tray, a tv screen tells how all the cows are being captured thus meaing no milk thus meaning everyone is left with 'dry cereal'.  In this crazy, anthropomorhic world, that's really all you need.  

Gameplay-wise, the point-and-click appraoch works smoothly, and it's always fun to see just how strange and bizarre the results could be for clicking in random areas.  One neat thing about this series (and the other series in HG's lineup) is the element of replayablilty, when you finish the game through one lot of paths you play again to go through an entirely different set, different puzzles to muck about with, different areas, and even the endings confronting antagonist William the Kid are different too, so you do feel these changes are having some sort of impact.  Nothing is too difficult and there is always advice from either Spy's watch or spy himself if you do ever happen to get stuck.  The only annoying puzzle I came across was the 'go-fish' game with the pig, hated his smug look so much when he was winning and it was so satisfying to wipe that smugness right of his face when you do get to beat him.  There's a little time-waster mini-game on Spy's watch too, which was okay, didn't really play around with it too much.  

Music was all decent too, did it's job in the game, but I wouldn't really listen to it outside of that.

Design and setting are where this game shines.  I really love the sharp style of the world which is all consistant.  It might not be perfect graphics-wise, but I'd still say it's pleasing to look at.  Almost like a saturday-morning cartoon in game form.  

In all I'd probably give this an 8/10, I had way too much fun out of this to dare give it anything lower, and a 10/10 for would definately give it to my kids to play someday.

14020852.review:
Добрая, детская игра про шпиона-лиса. 
______________________________
Я не знаю точно, сколько лет этой игре, судя по scumm-vm весьма немало, но сразу видно, что авторы этой игры вложили в нее душу. В игре тонна диалогов, музыка, озвучка - все на высоте. На фоне всегда можно найти мелкие элементы развлечения (поющие тараканы, медведь в гавайке верхом на айсберге и тому подобное). У каждого из персонажей, вне зависимости - играет ли он главную роль или просто стоит на фоне, есть свой характер, своя душа. Загадки продуманы, хотя и кажутся весьма простыми, но не следует забывать, что они делались для детей. Но самый главный шик этой игры - анимация. В игре проанимировано просто все. Предметы интерьера все время в движении, люди(ну, не совсем люди :D) все время что-то делают, а не стоят столбами, а в анимацию главного героя я просто влюбился - шикарно проработаное движение хвоста при ходьбе и прыжках и вообще.
В игре есть несколько вещей, которые оставляют после себя вопросы, например:
• Для чего нужен был ботинок? Я так и не нашёл куда его использвать.
• Почему ренген-жвачка остается после использования? Она же нужна только один раз.
• Для чего нужна игра в рыбу внизу? Сколько бы я не выигрывал - все, чего я добился, дак это того, что свинья стала потеть.
______________________________
В общем, эта игра придется по душе всем любителям визуальных квестов, детям и просто людям, которые хотят отдохнуть не особо запариваясь.
______________________________
Go fish, mr. Fox!

L'humour est très bien traité, ainsi que le côté wtf, comme on l'attend d'un jeu sur lequel a travaillé Ron Gilbert [le papa de Monkey Island et également fondateur d'Humongous!]. Facile d'accès pour les petits, attrayant, il a tout pour plaire.
Pour l'amour du Point&Click, trois hourra pour Spy Fox!

13351801.review:
"Sein Name ist Fuchs, Agent Fuchs und er würde seinen Martini wohl alkoholfrei und mit viel Kuhmilch trinken.
Ein Point and Click Adventure, das fast noch genau so gut ist, wie es damals in meiner Kindheit war." ~ BlackCat.XIII 2014

Story:
Der böse Willy V. Brecher hat einen diabolischen Plan. Als Oberhaupt der Gesellschaft für Ziegenmilch hat er alle Milchkühe der Welt gefangengenommen um das Milchmonopol zu erhalten. Außerdem plant er mit einer rießigen Sauermilchbombe aus Kuhmilch die Hauptstadt zu überschwemmen und diese Tat dann den armen Kühen in die Schuhe zu schieben. Doch er hat die Rechnung ohne Agent Fuchs gemacht, der sich sofort auf den Weg macht um diese Katastrophe zu stoppen.
Eine dümmere Geschichte hätte man sich wohl nicht ausdenken können, aber gerade das macht Spy Fox in Dry Cereal gerade so sympathisch. Das schöne daran ist, dass die Story nach dem Anfang 3 verschiedene Richtungen nehmen kann, die zwar alle zu dem selben Ende führen, aber durchaus etwas Abwechslung in die Sache bringen. So gilt es zum Entschärfen der Bombe entweder einen Schlüssel, eine Lochkarte oder ein Batteriedinges zu finden, welche jeweils an anderen Orten versteckt sind. Kleiner "Spoiler": Um das "richtige" Ende zu bekommen muss man gegen Ende nochmal flink sein und aufpassen.

Gameplay:
Ein Point and Click Adventure wie es im Buche steht, denn mehr als eine Maus braucht man nicht. Man klickt Personen an um mit ihnen zu reden, benutzt Pfeile am Bildschirmrand um sich zu bewegen und hämmert wie wahnsinnig auf Objekten herum, um sich über für Kinder durchaus unterhlatsame Spaßanimationen lustig zu machen. Das ganze läuft flüssig, ist zwar ein alter Hut, funktioniert aber gut.
Die Rätsel die es zu lösen gilt kann man kaum als solche bezeichnen, da die meisten ohne den richtigen Hinweis nicht und mit dem "Hinweis" zu 100% zu lösen sind. Allerdings gibt es ein paar Klickpasagen, in denen es auf das richtige Timing ankommt.

Präsentation:
Das ganze Spiel ist herrlich bunt und wird an verschiedenen Locations mit unterschiedlichen Musikstücken in Endloschleife untermalt. Die Characktere stammen alle aus dem Tierreich und besitzen jeweils eine eigene (auch deutsche ) Synchronstimme, die zwar nicht das beste ist, was man je gehört hat, aber trotzdem passend ist. 
Zudem besitzt das Spiel einen kindgerechten aber recht flachen Humor, der teilweise mit so schlechten Wortspielen um sich wirft, dass es schon wieder lustig ist.

Fazit:
Wenn man bedenkt, dass dieses Spiel eigentlich für Kinder gemacht wurde, darf man als nun Erwachsener wohl nicht allzuviel erwarten, doch hat es Spy Fox geschafft sich so sehr in mein Gedächtnis zu brennen, dass ich es mir nun auf Steam gekauft habe. Der Nostalgiefaktor war bei mir enorm groß und deshalb kann ich es mit gutem Gewissen all denen empfehlen, die damals dieses Spiel ( oder andere wie Pyjama Sam oder Putt Putt ) geliebt haben.
Allerdings sollten erwachsene Spieler wohl einen Sale abwarten, da sie für den vollen Preis ein etwas zu einfaches Point & Click Adventure bekommen würden, das allerdings sogar 2 Minispiele beinhaltet, die doch recht unterhaltsam sind.
Von welchem anderen Spiel kann man denn sonst behaupten, man habe mit einem Schwein namens Speckschwart in einem Jazzclub eine Partie Quartett um ein Stück Krimskrams gespielt?

Nominiert von mir für einen Steamaward ~

12667645.review: As a nostalgia trip this game is great. It still has some humor that's on point. Even sitting here at 23 I can still enjoy parts of this game just like when I was 8.  It's a very simplistic point and click that does have a few creative puzzles here and there. It can easily be finished in around 2 or 3 hours. I did it in just under 2. The only gripe I have with it is how long it takes to get from area to area. Spy Fox loves to do some pointless animations/ramble on about things everytime you enter certain rooms. Traveling across 5 screens should only take about 10 seconds but in Spy Fox it can take upwards of a minute! It will definitely get on your nerves after a while. Outside of that, it's Spy Fox. Unless you grew up with this or know someone younger who might enjoy this then there is really no other reason to get this. It's a pure nostalgia rush. Nothing more, nothing less.

12472991.review:
The best part of this simple point-and-click adventure is the witty dialogue. It's a game for children, but so much of the dialogue is surprisingly sophisticated with puns galore. You have to save the world's milk supply from a goat named William the Kid. You are transported onto the Island of Acidophilus. You have to enlist the help of a cow named Howard Hugh Heifer. And the puns go on.

Within the game, you have to use specific spy gadgets or items at specific points in the story. And the story actually changes somewaht on subsequent playthroughs, which is neat. It's all so light-hearted that I can't help but feel like a kid while playing the game.

11826274.review: Nostalgie pur! Eines meiner Lieblings Point&Click-Adventures, welches ich ursprünglich in der Cornflakes-Packung fand. Ein Plot mit viel Humor, erfrischende Animationen und passende Musik sorgen dafür, dass es ein breites Spektrum an Spielern anspricht. Sollte man mal nicht weiterkommen, sorgt das Fröhliche U-Boot (Minispiel mit Suchtfaktor) für Ablenkung.

11563179.review:
The first PC game I owned, and the one I played the most as a kid on the family computer. 

I was overjoyed to see that the Humongous Entertainment games we're released on steam, and immediately bought the few I could remember playing. This game is built upon nothing but James Bond references and parodies, and in saying that, it still has a great feel. The game changes each time you play it, and on a lonely day, I played through it some 7 times in a row, and I was still getting unique combinations of four or five different puzzles. 
As games stand today, I don't know if it would hold up comparatively to AAA point and click adventure games, like the Walking Dead Game, but it is a good game. (or I'm a crazy shell of a person, bending solely on the whim of nostalgia)

10595100.review: Engaged in bestiality. 11/10 would milk again.

10566435.review:
If you played this game as a kid, you won't regret replaying it as an adult. The writing and voice work are excellent, the art and animation are great (despite the low resolution) - for a kid's game at its time it was way ahead of the game. You'll see how much you missed as a kid (the PUNS, the REFERENCES, and the JUST PLAIN FUNNY STUFF THAT YOU DIDN'T GET BECAUSE OF UNDERDEVELOPED VOCABULARY). This game is awesome and hilarious. I think I'm enjoying it more, in fact, than I did as a child. I'm clicking on everything, because I want to hear every piece of dialogue (there are about three witty phrases for everything you click on). Also, the story changes every time you replay, into three(?) randomized configurations, AND they just made the UK version available to everyone (which I hear is just as funny, if not funnier, than the US version). Replayability is sky-rocketting.
Just buy it. Play it. And don't reconsider the purchase until then. Like I said, you don't be disappointed.

10403085.review: This game is blast from the past when things were much simpler.

10033902.review: 420/10 best game EVER SO STOP EVERYTHING AND GIVE THEM YOUR MONEIS!!!!!!!!!

10023514.review: Nice to see this game pop up again. It has that cheesey though amusing quality to it that I remember as a kid. The game's good for a chuckle, isn't too difficult to figure out, but has some smart writing. Multiple play-through options for completing it; it randomizes each time you start a new game. The VA work isn't too shabby for a PC game from 1997 (noticed that Professor Quack is voiced by the guy who does Bentley from Sly Cooper). Definitely good for the kiddies, or for an idiot like me -- a 24 year old looking for a smile to unwind after work.

9998162.review: A great blast from the past. Very short by today's standards, and easier than I remembered (after all, it's geared to children), but the humor, nostalgia and fun factors are super-high. Now if only LucasArts would reissue their classic point-and-click games!

9993489.review:
The game of ultimate nostalgia.

Spy Fox is a great game and only takes a couple hours (at most) to beat. It's so awesome to be able to replay a game that I used to play when I was a child. A wonderful blast-to-the-past game that you can play in your free time. C:

Also, you're a fox in a SUIT, who gets to play GoFish with a giant pig, and dance the tango with a beautiful feline. How awesome is that?!

9992558.review: Das Spiel ist schon ziemlich alt und dafür einfach nur tot lustig, Ein lustiges kleines Point and Click Adventure

9913612.review: one of the best humongous entertainment titles

9905685.review: Like James Bond, but with furries. 10/10.

9905623.review:
I used to play this game all the time when I was a little kid. I loved the theme and the cute spy story. Yeah everyone's a furry but it's not that big of a deal. It's replay ability is also very high, considering elements in the story change every time you play it. Some times you're going to have to find out how to tango with the russian enemy spy cat, some times play a highstakes game of go fish. It's childish but a great stetiotipical spy story. Also the nostalgia of playing this again after so many years was through the roof. Only complaint I had was the mouse was kinda buggy, enough so that is was fairly distracting. 

8/10 If you've played Spy Fox as a kid like me, you'll definitely love it.

9895569.review:
For those who grew up with the Spy Fox series will likely be the only ones who would appreciate the game for what it is.  I enjoyed picking up this blast-in-the-past game!  I never realized how many bad puns and play-on-words Fox does until now!  I didn't get half of them 15 years ago! XD

If you're looking for a game that has a bad pun every 2nd sentence, this game is for you.  And of course, if you're looking just pick up an old PC game.  I say go for it as well!

9885149.review: This is a game in which you play a fox James Bond who uses a whole slew of really crazy gadgets to foil a dasterdly plot to take over the world, and includes a Go Fish mini-game which is a lot of fun. Also, this game is my childhood. Buy it.

Excuse me while I go make up for 5 years' worth of cravings to play this game.

9876108.review: The single greatest game to ever grace Earth. Humongous Games are love. Humongous Games are life. Praise the sun for this great game.

9874723.review: This game brings back my childhood all the way. Point & Click, solve fun puzzles, gadgets galore, I mean, this game was my bread and butter when I was a kid. Actually, it still is my bread and butter! This is a must have if you remember Spy Fox! :)

9872544.review: my childhood. It might just be the nostalgia talking, but I would definitely recommend this.

9867210.review: A great nostalgia game for me.  Spy Fox was my first point & click adventure game and it continues to be my all time favorite.   It's not terribly hard but the music and quirky humor always puts a smile on my face. My future children shall play this game because what could be better then a furry version of James Bond?

9865219.review:
One of the first games I ever played on a PC, and it's just as funny as I remember it.

There are a few flaws (or differences from the ones you probably played):

1. Steam's version is a copy of the PAL version. It's got the UK voice actors. I personally don't mind it, but I'm sure some people will.

2. The game runs in "Slow machine mode" by default, and I have no idea how to change it. "Slow Machine mode" was a mode for computers in the 90s that just couldn't handle certain games. Therefore, the animation and stuff isn't what it could be. I personally don't mind, I played it in slow machine mode in the 90s anyway.

I'd wait until a patch is released to fix the 2 things listed up there if they bug you.

9863852.review:
I may have nostalgia in one eye (probably both), but this game is still as good as it ever was.

For anyone who has not played this game since the 90s, it's definitely worth a playthrough or two. Everything is the same as its original release, including all the voice actors. That being said, if you still have your CD copy of the game, there's nothing more to be found here beyond the convenience of Steam. The only added difference I could find during my playthrough was that Spacebar now pauses the game.

All this being said, I only recommend this game to those who want the nostalgia factor, or if the purchase is for a child. You'll be able to blaze through the whole story (one variant at least) in a half hour or less. If you use the Esc key, probably 10 minutes or less on a bad day. However, the game is meant for children, and I was certainly stuck at parts for quite a while as a child.

Fun Mini-games inside it to keep you entertained. Overall Solid Game of its time.

highly Recommend playing since its so cheap.

9858176.review: A fun game that brings a lot of nostalgia back to people, who played computer games when they were just kids. Unfortunatly, the game doesn't look as good as the HD re-release on the Wii. Still worth buying though and it comes in both the UK and US dubs!

9857498.review: My childhood is now on steam! I loved the Spy Fox games as a kid and now that humongous updated this game with the original US voices I love it even more! If you love point and clicks you have to buy this game, you are never to old for a humongous game :)

9857486.review:
What a masterpiece.

You'll be blown away by the gripping story, with plot twists at every turn.

The revolutionary gameplay is some of the most realistic the genre has ever seen, with amazing AI, and beautiful MS paint graphics.

While the FPS mechanics were kind of lacking, the gunplay was still very entertaining, and the sound design helped with the action, helping you pick out enemies based on sound. The quicktime events were also placed at the right moments, it made you feel like you were actually knocking on a door.

A great game for everyone, just wished they would have added more of the Horror elements that are displayed in the Putt-Putt games, but it's amazing overall.  10/10 would buy/play

9857039.review: I wasn't expecting such washed up puns, they were utterly terrible. Overall I think the game rates a solid 10/10 would tango.

9843106.review: As a millenial, I grew up on Humongous Entertainment games and was excited to see that they are re-releasing many of their old titles. Spy Fox was just charming as I remember it. I especially enjoyed picking up on a lot of the humor I missed as a child. My only complaint is that the voice actors, for reasons I cannot comprehend, are different. And they're just not getting it. If, like me, you played the original game enough to memorize all the nuances and inflections of the dialogue, the new voice acting will prove lackluster, irksome, and at times, distracting. Nonetheless, playing spy fox was a great nostalgic kick and I look forward to rediscovering more of the HE re-releases.
